awd_titl_txt: CRISP: Type 1: Reductionist and Integrative Approaches to Improve the Resiliency of Multi-Scale Interdependent Critical Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Critical infrastructures are evolving to be more diverse and increasingly connected. The growing complexity creates convoluted dependencies and interdependencies between infrastructures arising from cyber-physical, geographical, supply-and-demand, and human-in-the-loop relationships between different components of the system. Understanding these interactions requires a reductionist and an integrative approach. The reductionist approach focuses on studying the characteristics of four fundamental classes of dependency links, while the integrative approach uses them as building blocks to establish a holistic network framework to capture the interdependencies of the infrastructure systems. This bottom-up methodology provides a systematic way to generate an integrated and multi-scale view of a system of systems, enabling the identification and quantitative characterization of unanticipated interdependencies through feedback loops. The overarching goal of this project is to improve the resiliency of interdependent infrastructures, enabling them to recover from disruptive events and disturbances within an acceptable amount of time and cost.

The proposed research will expand the knowledge base of such interdependencies by adopting both reductionist and integration approach to create a bottom-up methodology to provide fundamental principles to understand interdependencies.  The project aims to classify and characterize four fundamental classes of dependencies using principles from physical laws, communications theory, supply chain theory, and game and economic theory. In addition, the project will develop automated scalable vertical and horizontal compositional techniques to form a holistic interdependency network model to investigate the fundamental tradeoff between heterogeneous measures, and the tradeoff between pre-event and post-event measures. The analysis of these relationships will lead to an optimal design of a multi-scale resilience mechanism, which will be applied to case study scenarios of Staten Island during Superstorm Sandy and a nuclear power plan accident such as the one that occurred in Fukushima, Japan.

por.por_cntn:
Infrastructures support the fabric of society. The resiliency has been increasingly compromised by extreme events. Complicating the ability to confront perturbations has been the interdependencies among infrastructures spatially and functionally. While these interconnections can provide economies of scale on the one hand, they can on the other hand produce inflexibilities that prevent the systems from resisting extreme event damages in a reasonable amount of time and for manageable costs. The intellectual merit of the research consists of the development and application of a wide range of models and frameworks across numerous types of infrastructures, extreme events, demographic and spatial characteristics. The research expands the knowledge of such systems and applicable models and frameworks   One outcome has been to evaluate tradeoffs between pre-event and post-event measures particularly for extreme weather conditions such as hurricanes. Models have been developed to suggest infrastructure designs to improve resilience that have been transferred to different case areas. The work has produced an understanding of how food systems interact with infrastructures as well as how those infrastructures relate to one another in a network framework.

 

This research has identified numerous connection points among interdependent infrastructures and has modeled these interactions. Case and event-based databases from various extreme events have for example identified connections between electric power outages and other infrastructures. One is the electric power-transit-road based transportation linkage. When transit is disabled, crowding of road networks occurs since it is substituted for transit. This in turn impacts the ability of workers and supplies to access electric power systems for recovery. This is illustrated by the 2003 blackout. A more localized disabling of electric power, for example, is when a large high voltage line was disrupted resulting in over a weeklong shutdown of the Metro North Railroad that is one mode electric power workers would use to get to repair sites. Another example is a three-way electric power, water, and transportation linkage. Water is dependent on electric power for water transport (e.g., pumping) and transportation (which is dependent on electric power) to receive chemicals and other supplies. Water in turn is critical for electric power production completing the feedback loop among those infrastructures. These and other relationships and the modeling that captures them have been published in articles and presented at professional conferences listed elsewhere in the report.

 

The broader impacts of the research are its applicability to a wide range of geographic areas that are similarly experiencing extreme events that have produced devastating impacts on infrastructure. Complex interdependent infrastructures are particularly compromised. The research has taken a multi-scaled approach integrating numerous combinations of infrastructures and applied them to cases applicable across a wide range of conditions. The research is also multi-disciplinary drawing upon physical laws, communications theory, supply chain theory, and game and economic theory. The educational value of the research has contributed to its social value by educating students who have worked on the project and communicating the results widely to a wide range of different audiences through dozens of presentations and publications.

 

One important outcome of this project is the development of computational tools for dynamic resiliency planning by taking into account the interconnection between socio-economic behaviors with the cyber and physical layers of critical infrastructures.  This tool is developed to strengthen the security and resilience of critical infrastructures by analyzing and modeling the relationships of different infrastructure components. To this end, we have built on previous results and developed a decision support tool called DRESIM, short for Dynamic Resilient Infrastructure Simulator and Management. See the attached flyer for the developed tool. The goal of DRESIM is to (1) identify critical nodes for recovery and restoration, (2) prioritize assistance to stabilize community lifelines, (3) plan to allocate resources to improve security and resiliency with budget constraints, (4) use information to predict and assess risks, and (5) inform and recommend actionable policies for threat prevention and resilience. The tools are based on the integrative economic and social models that will understand user choices, pricing, and quality of services, equality and fairness of infrastructure access in the context of interdependencies. This project will employ a set of scenarios based on categories of infrastructure user behavior to evaluate how such social dimensions affect infrastructure configurations, and conversely, how infrastructure configurations influence use of the system.
